      • 3. Known Product Limitations
        • 3.1. 17.0, 17.1 Only: vGPUs of different sizes on the same GPU are not supported
        • 3.2. NVENC does not support resolutions greater than 4096×4096
        • 3.3. vCS is not supported on VMware vSphere
        • 3.4. Nested Virtualization Is Not Supported by NVIDIA vGPU
        • 3.5. Issues occur when the channels allocated to a vGPU are exhausted
        • 3.6. Total frame buffer for vGPUs is less than the total frame buffer on the physical GPU
        • 3.7. Issues may occur with graphics-intensive OpenCL applications on vGPU types with limited frame buffer
        • 3.8. In pass through mode, all GPUs connected to each other through NVLink must be assigned to the same VM
        • 3.9. vGPU profiles with 512 Mbytes or less of frame buffer support only 1 virtual display head on Windows 10
        • 3.10. NVENC requires at least 1 Gbyte of frame buffer
        • 3.11. VM failures or crashes on servers with 1 TiB or more of system memory
        • 3.12. VM running an incompatible NVIDIA vGPU guest driver fails to initialize vGPU when booted
        • 3.13. Single vGPU benchmark scores are lower than pass-through GPU
        • 3.14. VMs configured with large memory fail to initialize vGPU when booted
      • 4. Resolved Issues
        • 4.1. Issues Resolved in Release 17.2
        • 4.2. Issues Resolved in Release 17.1
        • 4.3. Issues Resolved in Release 17.0
      • 5. Known Issues
        • 5.1. 17.0, 17.1 Only: XID error 120 causes multiple issues with NVIDIA vGPU on GPUs with a GSP
        • 5.2. 17.0, 17.1 Only: XID error 119 causes the hypervisor host to hang or crash when multiple vGPU VMs are shut down
        • 5.3. 17.0, 17.1 Only: Desktop is corrupted with XID errors 13 and 31 after vGPU VM is migrated or suspended and resumed
        • 5.4. vGPU VM fails to boot with error vmiop-display unable to reserve vgpu
        • 5.5. NVIDIA Control Panel is not available in multiuser environments
        • 5.6. NVIDIA Control Panel crashes if a user session is disconnected and reconnected
        • 5.7. VM assigned multiple fractional vGPUs from the same GPU hangs
        • 5.8. CUDA profilers cannot gather hardware metrics on NVIDIA vGPU
        • 5.9. NVIDIA vGPU software graphics driver for Windows sends a remote call to ngx.download.nvidia.com
        • 5.10. Multiple RDP session reconnections on Windows Server 2022 can consume all frame buffer
        • 5.11. VM with multiple legacy fractional vGPUs on the same GPU fails to boot
        • 5.12. NLS client fails to acquire a license with the error The allowed time to process response has expired
        • 5.13. With multiple active sessions, NVIDIA Control Panel incorrectly shows that the system is unlicensed
        • 5.14. VP9 and AV1 decoding with web browsers are not supported on Microsoft Windows Server 2019
        • 5.15. nvidia-smi ignores the second NVIDIA vGPU device added to a Microsoft Windows Server 2016 VM
        • 5.16. After an upgrade of the Linux graphics driver from an RPM package in a licensed VM, licensing fails
        • 5.17. After an upgrade of the Linux graphics driver from a Debian package, the driver is not loaded into the VM
        • 5.18. Desktop session freezes when a VM is migrated to or from a host running an NVIDIA vGPU software 14 release
        • 5.19. Application or vGPU VM crashes when multiple application instances are launched
        • 5.20. Only one vGPU VM can be powered on with VMware vSphere Hypervisor (ESXi) 7.0.3
        • 5.21. The reported NVENC frame rate is double the actual frame rate
        • 5.22. VM fails after a second vGPU is assigned to it
        • 5.23. NVENC does not work with Teradici Cloud Access Software on Windows
        • 5.24. When a licensed client deployed by using VMware instant clone technology is destroyed, it does not return the license
        • 5.25. A licensed client might fail to acquire a license if a proxy is set
        • 5.26. Session connection fails with four 4K displays and NVENC enabled on a 2Q, 3Q, or 4Q vGPU
        • 5.27. Disconnected sessions cannot be reconnected or might be reconnected very slowly with NVWMI installed
        • 5.28. Windows VM crashes during Custom (Advanced) driver upgrade
        • 5.29. VMs with vGPUs on GPUs based on the NVIDIA Ampere architecture fail to power on
        • 5.30. Linux VM hangs after vGPU migration to a host running a newer vGPU manager version
        • 5.31. Idle Teradici Cloud Access Software session disconnects from Linux VM
        • 5.32. GPU Operator doesn’t support vGPU on GPUs based on architectures before NVIDIA Turing
        • 5.33. Idle NVIDIA A100, NVIDIA A40, and NVIDIA A10 GPUs show 100% GPU utilization
        • 5.34. Driver upgrade in a Linux guest VM with multiple vGPUs might fail
        • 5.35. NVIDIA Control Panel fails to start if launched too soon from a VM without licensing information
        • 5.36. Citrix Virtual Apps and Desktops session corruption occurs in the form of residual window borders
        • 5.37. VMware Horizon clients cannot connect to a Windows 10 2004 VM with multiple displays
        • 5.38. Suspend and resume between hosts running different versions of the vGPU manager fails
        • 5.39. On Linux, a VMware Horizon 7.12 session freezes after a switch to full screen
        • 5.40. On Linux, a VMware Horizon 7.12 session with two 4K displays freezes
        • 5.41. On Linux, the frame rate might drop to 1 after several minutes
        • 5.42. Frame buffer consumption grows with VMware Horizon over Blast Extreme
        • 5.43. DWM crashes randomly occur in Windows VMs
        • 5.44. Remote desktop session freezes with assertion failure and XID error 43 after migration
        • 5.45. Citrix Virtual Apps and Desktops session freezes when the desktop is unlocked
        • 5.46. NVIDIA vGPU software graphics driver fails after Linux kernel upgrade with DKMS enabled
        • 5.47. Red Hat Enterprise Linux and CentOS 6 VMs hang during driver installation
        • 5.48. Tesla T4 is enumerated as 32 separate GPUs by VMware vSphere ESXi
        • 5.49. Users’ sessions may freeze during vMotion migration of VMs configured with vGPU
        • 5.50. Migration of VMs configured with vGPU stops before the migration is complete
        • 5.51. ECC memory settings for a vGPU cannot be changed by using NVIDIA X Server Settings
        • 5.52. Changes to ECC memory settings for a Linux vGPU VM by nvidia-smi might be ignored
        • 5.53. Black screens observed when a VMware Horizon session is connected to four displays
        • 5.54. Host core CPU utilization is higher than expected for moderate workloads
        • 5.55. H.264 encoder falls back to software encoding on 1Q vGPUs with a 4K display
        • 5.56. H.264 encoder falls back to software encoding on 2Q vGPUs with 3 or more 4K displays
        • 5.57. Frame capture while the interactive logon message is displayed returns blank screen
        • 5.58. RDS sessions do not use the GPU with some Microsoft Windows Server releases
        • 5.59. VMware vMotion fails gracefully under heavy load
        • 5.60. View session freezes intermittently after a Linux VM acquires a license
        • 5.61. When the scheduling policy is fixed share, GPU utilization is reported as higher than expected
        • 5.62. nvidia-smi reports that vGPU migration is supported on all hypervisors
        • 5.63. GPU resources not available error during VMware instant clone provisioning
        • 5.64. Module load failed during VIB downgrade from R390 to R384
        • 5.65. On Linux, 3D applications run slowly when windows are dragged
        • 5.66. A segmentation fault in DBus code causes nvidia-gridd to exit on Red Hat Enterprise Linux and CentOS
        • 5.67. No Manage License option available in NVIDIA X Server Settings by default
        • 5.68. Licenses remain checked out when VMs are forcibly powered off
        • 5.69. Memory exhaustion can occur with vGPU profiles that have 512 Mbytes or less of frame buffer
        • 5.70. vGPU VM fails to boot in ESXi if the graphics type is Shared
        • 5.71. GNOME Display Manager (GDM) fails to start on Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.2 and CentOS 7.0
        • 5.72. NVIDIA Control Panel fails to start and reports that “you are not currently using a display that is attached to an Nvidia GPU”
        • 5.73. VM configured with more than one vGPU fails to initialize vGPU when booted
        • 5.74. A VM configured with both a vGPU and a passthrough GPU fails to start the passthrough GPU
        • 5.75. vGPU allocation policy fails when multiple VMs are started simultaneously
        • 5.76. Before Horizon agent is installed inside a VM, the Start menu’s sleep option is available
        • 5.77. vGPU-enabled VMs fail to start, nvidia-smi fails when VMs are configured with too high a proportion of the server’s memory.
        • 5.78. On reset or restart VMs fail to start with the error VMIOP: no graphics device is available for vGPU…
        • 5.79. nvidia-smi shows high GPU utilization for vGPU VMs with active Horizon sessions
  • Virtual GPU and Pass-Through GPU
